          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Della Plumstone do next in this situation?
          Answer: Della Plumstone should offer Lennon Figtree 4 coins for the basket.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in Fruitville who is trying to make a profit by negotiating prices with customers. He recently had a successful deal with Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently trying to make a deal with Della Plumstone. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, between 12:10 AM and 12:15 AM.

He recently had a successful deal with Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently trying to make a deal with Della Plumstone. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, between 12:10 AM and 12:15 AM.

        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they helped their father set up a stall at the local market, learning the art of haggling and the importance of fair trade. This experience sparked a love for commerce and a desire to bring fresh produce to those who needed it most.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they used their savings to buy a small plot of land and planted a variety of fruit trees. They learned about the cycle of growth and the satisfaction of nurturing something from seed to fruit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo journey as a travelling fruit merchant, their wagon loaded with apples, pears, and plums. They bartered their wares for necessities and shared their surplus with those less fortunate.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a community ravaged by famine. Lennon shared their entire stock of fruit, refusing payment and vowing to return with more when they had restocked their wagon.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 3 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in Fruitville who is trying to make a profit by negotiating prices with customers like Della Plumstone. He recently made a successful deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 3 coins or reject it.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer.
          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 0
      Lennon Figtree: 0
      Joint action
    • {'Della Plumstone': '1 coin', 'Lennon Figtree': 'reject'}

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Scene 8 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, you know I'm a fair woman, but five coins is my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins? Della, you drive a hard bargain yourself.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market.           Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville trying to negotiate a price with Della Plumstone, who wants to buy his fruit for a lower price than he paid for it.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can accept Della Plumstone's offer, reject it, or make a counteroffer.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to make a counteroffer.

        • 1895-09-16 00:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, you know I'm a fair woman, but five coins is my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins? Della, you drive a hard bargain yourself.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Della Plumstone?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a shrewd and ambitious businesswoman.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Della Plumstone in right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is currently in a negotiation.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Della Plumstone do next in this situation?
          Answer: Della Plumstone should try to find out Cedric Meadowbrook's reservation price.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Della Plumstone do next in this situation?
          Answer: Della Plumstone should offer Cedric Meadowbrook a price slightly higher than her previous offer.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.

          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now.           Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, they successfully negotiated a trade with a notoriously shrewd merchant. Della had bartered a basket of their father's prized pears for a rare variety of citrus fruit, using their quick wit and sharp observation skills to secure a favorable deal. The experience solidified Della's natural talent for bargaining and fueled their ambition to build their own trading business.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Della Plumstone should use her sharp bargaining skills to negotiate a favorable price for the fruit, keeping in mind her knowledge of market prices and her desire to maximize profit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          Answer: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook at a price that will allow her to make a profit when she resells them.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Della Plumstone?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a shrewd and ambitious businesswoman.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Della Plumstone in right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is currently in a negotiation.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Della Plumstone do next in this situation?
          Answer: Della Plumstone should offer Cedric Meadowbrook a price slightly higher than her previous offer, demonstrating a willingness to compromise while still aiming for a profitable deal.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Della Plumstone do next in this situation?
          Answer: Della Plumstone should try to find out Cedric Meadowbrook's reservation price.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (c)

        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Della Plumstone should offer Lennon Figtree a price slightly higher than 2 coins, but still lower than her maximum willingness to pay of 6 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Della Plumstone is a shrewd and ambitious businesswoman.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      Stage index
    • 0

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell peaches to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering 4 coins for the peaches.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell peaches to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering 4 coins for the peaches.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

          Key

          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic.           Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 1.0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 2.0
      Joint action
    • {'Della Plumstone': '4 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Scene 10 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, you know I'm a fair woman, but five coins is my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins? Della, you drive a hard bargain yourself.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Summary of recent observations:
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market, aiming to make a profit.           Cedric Meadowbrook's The current date/time is:
          17 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market. He recently secured a deal with Della Plumstone for peaches and is currently in negotiations with Lennon Figtree.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market. He recently secured a deal with Della Plumstone for peaches and is currently in negotiations with Lennon Figtree.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he helped his father sell their meager harvest of apples at the market. The vibrant colors of the fruit did little to lift his spirits, and he found himself counting down the hours until he could return to the solitude of his room.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he traveled with the merchant, learning the art of bartering and the intricacies of the fruit trade. He found a strange satisfaction in the transactional nature of his work, in the fleeting moments of connection forged over a shared love of fruit.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market, aiming to make a profit. He successfully negotiated a deal with Della Plumstone for peaches and is currently negotiating with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market, aiming to make a profit. He successfully negotiated a deal with Della Plumstone for peaches and is currently negotiating with Lennon Figtree.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.

          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "That's fair, Cedric. Let's make it official then.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "That's fair, Cedric. Let's make it official then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, you know I'm a fair woman, but five coins is my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins? Della, you drive a hard bargain yourself.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. These are prime peaches, the juiciest in all of Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always appreciate your quality produce, but I'm running a business too. I need to make a profit when I sell these peaches back home.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "That's fair, Cedric. Let's make it official then.

          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they helped their father set up a stall at the local market, learning the art of haggling and the importance of fair trade. This experience sparked a love for commerce and a desire to bring fresh produce to those who needed it most.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they used their savings to buy a small plot of land and planted a variety of fruit trees. They learned about the cycle of growth and the satisfaction of nurturing something from seed to fruit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo journey as a travelling fruit merchant, their wagon loaded with apples, pears, and plums. They bartered their wares for necessities and shared their surplus with those less fortunate.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a community ravaged by famine. Lennon shared their entire stock of fruit, refusing payment and vowing to return with more when they had restocked their wagon.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Lennon, you drive a hard bargain, but you've got yourself a deal.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at a good price so she can resell it for a profit. They have successfully negotiated a deal.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can negotiate a price with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Cedric Meadowbrook.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Scene 11 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they helped their father set up a stall at the local market, learning the art of haggling and the importance of fair trade. This experience sparked a love for commerce and a desire to bring fresh produce to those who needed it most.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they used their savings to buy a small plot of land and planted a variety of fruit trees. They learned about the cycle of growth and the satisfaction of nurturing something from seed to fruit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo journey as a travelling fruit merchant, their wagon loaded with apples, pears, and plums. They bartered their wares for necessities and shared their surplus with those less fortunate.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a community ravaged by famine. Lennon shared their entire stock of fruit, refusing payment and vowing to return with more when they had restocked their wagon.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is negotiating the price of fruit with Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market square. She intends to resell the fruit for a profit in her hometown.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit, as she intends to resell it for a profit in her hometown.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 1 coin
          Answer: (c)

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook successfully completed a deal with Della Plumstone and is currently negotiating a sale with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these peaches are the finest you'll find this side of the river.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, those peaches do look fine, but I can only offer you 4 coins for them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 3 coins for a basket. It's a tough market out there, you know.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, with all due respect, I paid a coin apiece for these beauties. Three coins for the whole basket isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, you know these peaches are worth every penny. I can't let them go for that price.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these are lovely peaches, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.

He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "That's fair, Cedric. Let's make it official then.
